results.title: Across the Antarctica: a transatlantic view
results.brief_description: In an interview with Robert Mackenzie two members of the Commonwealth Trans-Antarctic Expedition - the leader Dr. Vivian Fuchs and Sir Edmund Hillary, in charge of the New Zealand party - discuss details of the plans for crossing the Antarctic Continent during 1955/58.

results.title: Across Canada with Princess Elizabeth
results.brief_description: A memorable record of the 15,000 mile tour of Canada by Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh. Opening with the Royal couple’s tumultuous reception in Quebec, the film covers the full extent of the tour. Narrated by Bernard Braden and Barbera Kelly.

results.title: Acropolis Now
results.credit_line:
Courtesy Crawford DVD

Acropolis Now is held in the collection of the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: In the 1980s, roles for Greek actors were limited, so they created their own - first the stage show Wogs out of Work (1987), and then the sitcom Acropolis Now, one of the first TV shows to bring much-needed diversity to Australian screens.

constellations_primary.name: Culture, food and family
constellations_primary.description: Food as a link to culture and family.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_other.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

results.description:
After World War II, Greek cinema circuits spread across Australia and were an epicentre of Greek community, language and culture that influenced many future filmmakers, such as Ana Kokkinos.

In the 1980s, roles for Greek actors were limited, so they created their own - first the stage show Wogs out of Work (1987), and then the sitcom Acropolis Now, one of the first TV shows to bring much-needed diversity to Australian screens. Besides the perfectly timed one-liners and unforgettable characters like Jim (Nick Giannopoulos) and Effie (Mary Coustas), it gave second-generation Greek Australians control of how they were portrayed - and what was acceptable to laugh at - and defied racial stereotypes that non-Greek actors, like The Comedy Company‘s Con the Fruiterer (Mark Mitchell), perpetuated on Australian TV.
description_for_label:
After World War II, Greek cinema circuits spread across Australia and were an epicentre of Greek community, language and culture that influenced many future filmmakers, such as Ana Kokkinos.

In the 1980s, roles for Greek actors were limited, so they created their own - first the stage show Wogs out of Work (1987), and then the sitcom Acropolis Now, one of the first TV shows to bring much-needed diversity to Australian screens. Besides the perfectly timed one-liners and unforgettable characters like Jim (Nick Giannopoulos) and Effie (Mary Coustas), it gave second-generation Greek Australians control of how they were portrayed - and what was acceptable to laugh at - and defied racial stereotypes that non-Greek actors, like The Comedy Company‘s Con the Fruiterer (Mark Mitchell), perpetuated on Australian TV.
results.credit_line_for_label:
Courtesy Crawford DVD

Acropolis Now is held in the collection of the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

results.title: Acrobats of God (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Dave Wilson, H Poindexter and Martha Graham Centre for Contemporary Dance
results.brief_description: Presents Martha Graham and her company in a dance performance which celebrates the trials, discipline, denials, glories, and delights of a dancer’s world. Choreography by Martha Graham. Music by Carlos Surinach.
